channel.title: AlumniUG on Dávalos Lab
channel.description: Recent content in AlumniUG on Dávalos Lab

item.title: Bhavana Patil
item.description: <!-- I am currently a premed sophomore studying biochemistry at Stony Brook. My research at the Davalos lab focuses on an MHC (M10.7) involved in the vomeronasal system, a system whose presence varies greatly in bats. My hopes are to find a correlation between a mutation in M10.7 and a lack of the vomeronasal organ; and its phylogenetic implications. -->

item.title: John Navillo
item.description: <!-- I am currently a sophomore majoring in human evolutionary biology and am aiding Marianne Moore on the White Nose Syndrome skin immune protein study. I am helping identify Pseudogymnoascus destructans, the fungus that causes WNS, on bat skin swab samples using real time PCR (qPCR). I am also researching and developing a knowledge base that will help our methodological considerations of the proteomics aspect of the study. I look forward to researching such an important ecological issue. -->

item.title: Sanah Afzal
item.description: <!-- To be able to taste is one of the major five senses in any animal. Being able to taste food provides an animal with nutrition and it helps to protect them against things that could potentially cause harm. The first time I heard that a carnivorous bat could have a broken gene preventing them from tasting sweet things, I was fascinated. I started to question how and why this could occur. This sparked the birth of my research. My research project delves deeper into the inner workings of a gene called Tas1r2. This gene allows a bat to taste sweet things, which helps the bat recognize that it is eating foods rich with nutritious carbohydrates and proteins. The major objective of my project is to observe whether this gene is conserved or psuedogenized throughout various species of bats. My project divides the species of bats I wanted to analyze into two categories, carnivorous bats, and nectarivorous bats. My results will be analyzed helping me find the answers I desire. In the future, I want to become a lab researcher who focuses on genetics. This research is an amazing experience to attain these goals which makes me excited. I cannot wait for what the future holds. -->

item.title: Sarah Heder
item.description: <!-- I am a senior studying biology at Stony Brook. I am researching the evolution of olfactory receptors in frugivorous bats. Bats are a very diverse order of mammals that have evolved to utilize a variety of different food sources, and my research involves quantifying phylogenetic instability in olfactory receptor gene families to determine whether there has been selective pressure on the duplication and loss of these genes in the Stenodermatinae subfamily as a result of their difference in diet compared to other Phyllostomids -->
